text: The sheriff of Los Angeles County reiterated this week that he would not compel members of his staff to be inoculated against the coronavirus, in defiance of the county’s order that all of its 110,000 employees show proof of vaccination by Oct. 1.

headline: The Film Industry Wants to Keep the Status Quo? Then Shut It Down.
text: In 2015, Cutter Ray Palacios, an actor from Texas, moved to Los Angeles. While auditioning for roles, he found himself working primarily as a production assistant (P.A.), a job that can entail transporting actors to and from set, moving equipment, sorting mail and running errands for producers or other members of the crew.

headline: Andrea Elliott on ‘Invisible Child’
text: In 2013, the front page of The New York Times devoted five straight days to the story of Dasani, an 11-year-old Black girl who lived in a homeless shelter in Brooklyn. Now, Andrea Elliott, the reporter of that series, has published her first book, “Invisible Child,” which tells the full story of Dasani and her family up to the present day. On this week’s podcast, Elliott discusses how she came to focus her reporting on Dasani.

headline: Disney World reveals how much its new line-skipping system will cost.
text: Disney theme park fans, prepare to dig a little deeper. Walt Disney World released more information about its new paid line-skipping system on Friday, and complete access will add roughly $40 to the price of daily park entry, which already costs $109 to $159 for adults, depending on the day. The system will debut on Oct. 19.

headline: Biden’s Pick to Lead N.E.A. Sees Culture as a Community Building Tool
text: President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s new nominee to lead the National Endowment for the Arts is a veteran arts administrator and tenured professor at Arizona State University with a background in urban planning and a history of embracing the importance of the arts at the neighborhood level.

headline: First Up in La MaMa’s Return: Strange, Enchanting Puppetry
text: Sonia enters naked, far upstage. Even from a distance, she is an imposing presence, taller than either of the men who are helping her walk.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
text: The second full winter of the coronavirus is on the horizon, and soon, many of us will be headed indoors where the risk of transmission of the virus is greater.

headline: A Thanksgiving Tribute to the McIntosh Apple
text: Let’s take a Thanksgiving break from politics, the coronavirus pandemic and the economy to focus on an important element of the holiday: food.

headline: Kyrsten Sinema Wants to Cut $100 Billion in Proposed Climate Funds, Sources Say
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, who began her political career with the Green Party and who has voiced alarm over the warming planet, wants to cut at least $100 billion from climate programs in major legislation pending on Capitol Hill, according to two people familiar with the matter.

headline: ‘Late Night’ LaMonte, Pinch-Hit Homers and a Closer From Nowhere
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Along with a franchise-record 107 victories, and a cascading list of things that contributed to them, the San Francisco Giants have been able to fill one gaping modern-era void. In a time starved for great nicknames like Dizzy (Dean), Three-Finger (Brown) or Catfish (Hunter), the Giants have introduced “Late Night” LaMonte Wade Jr.

headline: Can the Rule of Three Solve All My Dressing Problems?
text: There are actually many and varied rules of three in the world. Why? Because, as “Schoolhouse Rock” told us all in 1973, “three is a magic number.” It is the smallest number required to create a pattern, and patterns are how humans process information.

headline: N.B.A. star Kyrie Irving could lose at least $380,000 over vaccination status.
text: With the Nets star Kyrie Irving potentially set to lose more than $380,000 for missing a preseason game Friday night, the N.B.A. players’ association pushed back on the league’s plan to dock the pay of unvaccinated players for any games they miss this season because of local coronavirus ordinances.

headline: Court in Argentina Dismisses Charges Against Kirchner in Bombing Case
text: BUENOS AIRES — A court in Argentina has dismissed a criminal case against Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner that accused her of conspiring with Iran to cover up that country’s suspected involvement in a 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires.

headline: Biden Signs Legislation to Compensate Victims of Mysterious ‘Havana Syndrome’
text: President Biden signed into law on Friday a new government program to compensate C.I.A. officers, State Department diplomats and other federal officials who have suffered traumatic neurological injuries that the intelligence community has yet to figure out, launched by assailants it cannot yet identify.

headline: The S.E.C. has issued a subpoena to Archegos, the $10 billion firm that collapsed spectacularly.
text: Lawyers with the Securities and Exchange Commission have served a subpoena on Archegos Capital Management, the $10 billion family investment office that suddenly collapsed in March, roiling the stock market as its losses reverberated through the banking industry.

headline: Peter C. Bunnell, 83, Dies; Brought Academic Rigor to History of Photography
text: Peter C. Bunnell, who over a 35-year career at the Museum of Modern Art and Princeton University transformed the history of photography from a side interest among professional photographers to a rigorous academic discipline, died on Sept. 20 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 83.

headline: Jobs, Nobel Peace Prize, M.L.B. Playoffs: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Benefits for All or Just the Needy? Manchin’s Demand Focuses Debate
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia has a ready retort to fellow Democrats who say shrinking the party’s social safety net bill will mean depriving vulnerable populations of critical resources: Limit access to every program in the ambitious measure to only those Americans who need it most.

headline: What Is Facebook Worth to Us?
text: It is easy to forget how new Facebook is, but remember I do. The first time I logged in to the social networking site was around 2006. I was taking classes in an adult enrichment program at a small Catholic school in Charlotte, N.C. A young literature professor used Facebook to cultivate informal communication with the traditional-age students. I joined Facebook using my university email address, which at the time was required to sign up.

headline: Trump Hotel Lost Money, Despite Lobbyist Spending, Documents Show
text: WASHINGTON — Despite all the Republican-paid political events and big bar tabs from lobbyists, foreign dignitaries and other supporters of President Donald J. Trump, the Trump International Hotel in Washington lost an estimated $74 million between 2016 and 2020, according to data released on Friday by House investigators.

headline: Raiders Coach Made Racist Comment About N.F.L. Players’ Union Chief
text: Jon Gruden, the coach of the Las Vegas Raiders, in 2011 used racist terms to denounce DeMaurice Smith, the executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association, who is Black and has been facing opposition within the union to the extension of his contract.

headline: At Mexico-U.S. Security Talks, Migration Question Is Largely Avoided
text: MEXICO CITY — The United States and Mexico began overhauling an aged security agreement on Friday to better confront the flow of criminal activity between the two nations, but officials at the high-level talks conspicuously sought to avoid focusing on the ever-growing migrant crisis on their shared border.

headline: Apple Appeals App Store Ruling in Fight With Epic Games
text: Apple asked a federal appeals court on Friday to throw out a legal decision that would require the tech giant to tweak its strict App Store rules and force it to allow app developers to inform customers of ways to pay for subscriptions and services outside the App Store.

headline: Police Standoff With Man in a Tree Ends on the Third Day
text: The police arrived at Roody Thomas’s home in Queens shortly before 1 p.m. Wednesday for what seemed like a typical call of a domestic disturbance.

headline: McConnell Warns Biden He Won’t Help Raise the Debt Ceiling Next Time
text: WASHINGTON — A day after dropping his party’s blockade and allowing action to temporarily increase the federal debt ceiling, Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, warned President Biden on Friday that he had no intention of doing so again, reviving the threat of a first-ever federal default in December.

headline: See How Britain’s Gas Shortages Became a Crisis Overnight
text: New data reveals how panic buying drained supplies, exacerbating a problem stemming from a lack of trained drivers to make fuel deliveries.

headline: A Pitchers’ Duel Is Decided by a Mighty Swing
text: MILWAUKEE — Corbin Burnes stood alone on the mound on Friday, a triangle of trouble already threatening to swamp the Milwaukee Brewers in a playoff game’s first inning.

headline: Trouble Comes for Big Tech
text: Could Jonathan Kanter have better timing?

headline: With Textbook Win, the Astros Take a Commanding Series Lead
text: HOUSTON — If you kept score at Minute Maid Park on Friday, you might have felt like a grade-school teacher with a class full of honor students, scribbling little stars onto paper all day. The Houston Astros’ defense was just that dazzling.

headline: More Than Discouraged
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — August Lee-Kovach is the 70th crossword constructor to make a Times debut so far this year. That’s a lot of new voices, which is a great harbinger of puzzles to come. (It’s also nice that several of those newbies have made two or more 2021 grids and begun to feel like regulars.)

headline: Most Abortions in Texas Are Banned Again After Court Ruling
text: HOUSTON — A federal appeals court panel reinstated Texas’ restrictive abortion law late Friday, temporarily restoring a ban on virtually all procedures that had been blocked by a lower court two days earlier in a case brought by the Biden administration.

headline: Chicago’s mayor guts the city’s vaccine mandate for public workers.
text: Just a day after President Biden visited Chicago to plead for vaccine mandates, saying they were the only way to defeat the coronavirus, Mayor Lori Lightfoot on Friday said public workers could opt out of the city’s mandate until the end of the year by getting regularly tested.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Journalists in Philippines and Russia Are Cited for Courage
text: “The fight against the media is not a fight against the media. It is a fight against the people.”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 9, 2021
text: An article on Friday about the new malaria vaccine in Africa referred incorrectly to malaria in one instance. It is caused by a parasite, not a virus.

headline: Deontay Wilder and Tyson Fury: A Trilogy Defined by Its Twists
text: LAS VEGAS — For more than 30 minutes, the two combatants talked relatively calmly to each other as the room became thick with tension as each man nonchalantly described what violence he would unleash on the other.

headline: Red Sox Prove ‘Hitting Is Contagious’ in Series-Tying Win
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Boston Red Sox are an imperfect team. They made the second most fielding errors in the major leagues during the regular season. Their pitching staff ranked, depending on the statistic, in the top third or middle of the pack. But make no mistake, they can absolutely crush the ball.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Debate Looms Over I.M.F.: Should It Do More Than Put Out Fires?
text: Lopsided access to vaccinations, extreme economic inequality, rising food prices and staggering debt are on the agenda when the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank gather for their annual meetings in Washington next week.

headline: As Johnson Draws a Happy Face, Britons Confront a Run of Bad News
text: LONDON — Britons are lining up for gas, staring at empty grocery shelves, paying higher taxes and worrying about spiraling prices as a grim winter approaches.

headline: Paradise Was Lost. She’s Telling Its Stories.
text: Images of the wildfire that devastated Paradise, Calif., in 2018 are hard to forget. Known as the Camp Fire — after Camp Creek Road, where it started — the disaster killed at least 85 people and essentially destroyed the entire town. Lizzie Johnson was a reporter at The San Francisco Chronicle at the time, and her new book, “Paradise,” is a vivid ticktock account of the disaster, told through the stories of those who experienced it. Johnson, now a reporter at The Washington Post, talks about the fire as a turning point, how the scope and structure of her book changed over time and more.

headline: Her Hyper-Realistic Art Is a Parallel Universe
text: Name: Ariana Papademetropoulos

headline: The Zambian Economist at the Crossroads of Global Business
text: For policymakers and business leaders seeking simple answers to complex problems, Dambisa Moyo is a valuable sounding board. With a Ph.D. in economics from Oxford, a master of public administration from Harvard and experience serving on the boards of companies like Chevron, 3M and Barclays, Ms. Moyo has the kind of broad exposure and macroeconomic knowledge that is often lacking in the upper reaches of siloed organizations.

headline: ‘A Safe Space’: Black Pastors Promote Vaccinations from the Pulpit
text: Dozens of people gathered at the Word of Life International Church in the South Bronx on a recent Saturday for its weekly food bank, but the pastor wanted to ask the crowd a question before the groceries were handed out: Did anyone know where to find the closest vaccination site?

headline: Passing the Time With a Piano-Playing Pilot
text: It’s after midnight at the Palm Court in Cincinnati and staff is trying to close. Lights are dimmed as the last of the martini glasses and beer bottles are scooped up. But Beau Brant is still at the piano, playing for stragglers.

headline: Back in Lesbian Paradise, at Long Last
text: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — In late September, when thousands of people descended on the Hilton Palm Springs for a marathon weekend of pool parties, concerts and club nights, it had been close to 19 months since Covid-19 put life as we knew it on pause — not to mention, more than two years since this desert city had been transformed into a lively lesbian oasis.

headline: Lawmakers See Path to Rein In Tech, but It Isn’t Smooth
text: WASHINGTON — “Facebook and Big Tech are facing a Big Tobacco moment,” Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, said this week when a whistle-blower testified about how the social media company’s products harmed teenagers.

headline: First, Impressive Vaccines for Covid. Next Up: The Flu.
text: As the world grapples with Covid-19, influenza isn’t getting much attention these days. But the flu’s global impact is staggering: three million to five million cases of severe illness every year, and up to 650,000 deaths. Every few decades, a new flu strain spills over from animals and leads to a pandemic.

headline: Why I’m Ending My ‘Wealth Matters’ Column
text: When I told the deputy business editor a few months ago that I wanted to end my weekly “Wealth Matters” column we agreed on this weekend. I said it would be No. 608. He joked that might qualify me for the Hall of Fame.

headline: Candidate for ‘Mayah’ Proudly Leans Into Her Boston Sound
text: BOSTON — The mayoral candidate Annissa Essaibi George was amping up her supporters, who had gathered in an Italian restaurant on the waterfront, a little punchy after a long day of getting out the vote.

headline: The Real Trials of a ‘Real Housewife’
text: From a bit part as a dead body on “Law & Order” to six seasons on “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills,” television has been a crucial part of Erika Girardi’s careful cultivation of her branded glamorous life.

headline: Lifestyles of the Rich and Gullible: Theranos and Ozy Edition
text: Ozy Media told investors it had “strong financial performance, seemingly impressive viewership metrics and significant institutional investor interest,” according to a firm that heard the pitch. In return, it got $2 million in funding, adding to its $83 million haul. Last week, that firm sued, alleging fraud and concealment.

headline: At Rwanda’s Favorite Bars, Forget the Beer: Milk Is What’s on Tap
text: KIGALI, Rwanda — As the sun scorched the hilly Rwandan capital on a recent afternoon, a motorcycle taxi driver, two women in matching head scarves and a teenager wearing headphones all separately sauntered into a small roadside kiosk to drink the only thing on tap: milk.

headline: ‘Starting a Fire’: U.S. and China Enter Dangerous Territory Over Taiwan
text: The 25 Chinese fighter jets, bombers and other warplanes flew in menacing formations off the southern end of Taiwan, a show of military might on China’s National Day, Oct. 1. The incursions, dozens upon dozens, continued into the night and the days that followed and surged to the highest numbers ever on Monday, when 56 warplanes tested Taiwan’s beleaguered air defenses.

headline: Months Before Oil Spill, Pipeline May Have Taken Quiet Damage
text: The pipeline that spilled at least 126,000 gallons of oil into the Pacific Ocean off the California coast may have been damaged up to a year earlier, according to preliminary results of an ongoing investigation, the U.S. Coast Guard said.

headline: Philippines’ Nobel Prize Newsroom Is Overjoyed but Under Siege
text: The young editors and reporters of the Philippine news site Rappler were already busy on Friday. It was the last day candidates could file to run in next year’s elections, and the journalists were watching to see who would try to replace Rodrigo Duterte, the president who for years has attacked Rappler and threatened its staff members.

headline: In Debate Over Conquistadors 500 Years Ago, Spanish Right Sees an Opportunity
text: MADRID — In a letter to Mexican bishops last month, Pope Francis called for a revisiting of the country’s history, especially the role of the Roman Catholic Church, and urged clergy members to “recognize the painful errors committed in the past.”

headline: Shades of Another Giants Era: A Youngster Tames the Dodgers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When the San Francisco Giants won three World Series titles over the five-year period from 2010-14, they did so with young pitchers blossoming at just the right time. Without Tim Lincecum, Matt Cain and Madison Bumgarner, the Giants would not have risen to such heights.

headline: Michael Dell Is Trying to Be Nice
text: Books about deal making are the thrillers of the business world. There is conflict. There are high stakes. There is bluffing, bragging and bullying. There are “Barbarians at the Gate.”

headline: 6 Marathons in 6 Weeks? Shalane Flanagan Has 4 More to Go, and 2 This Weekend.
text: With the world’s six major marathons — Berlin, London, Chicago, Boston, Tokyo and New York City — squeezed into a six-week window this fall, most top runners had a tough decision to make.

headline: For Seasoned Soccer Travelers, No Other Trip Qualifies
text: One of the essential, and unsung, experiences in American sports fandom requires you to leave American soil altogether.

headline: Serial Killer Gets 160 Years After Victim’s Sister and Friends Help Solve Case
text: When Sarah Butler did not return to her home in Montclair, N.J., after borrowing her mother’s minivan in November 2016, her family immediately recognized that she might be in trouble.

headline: Can My Landlord Put Locks in My Apartment That I Can’t Open?
text: Q: I am renting a condo in a large Manhattan building. The bedrooms and one of the closets have deadbolt locks that can only be locked or unlocked with a key from the outside. The landlord will not give us keys to the locks. This seems like a serious safety issue, especially if there are children living in the apartment. Are these types of locks allowed on bedroom doors? If so, is the landlord required to provide us with a key to each lock? She has also suggested that if we want these locks removed, we will have to pay for that.

headline: A Delta-driven surge is pushing hospitals in North Dakota to the brink.
text: While the Delta variant-driven surge is receding in much of the United States, it rages on in less-vaccinated states like North Dakota, to the point where the state’s governor and health professionals have asked people to avoid risky activities that could add to the burden on hospitals.

headline: A Language Bill Deepens a Culture Clash in Quebec
text: MONTREAL — Since Aude Le Dubé opened an English-only bookshop in Montreal last year, she has had several unwelcome guests each month: Irate Francophones, sometimes draped in Quebec flags, who storm in and berate her for not selling books in French.

headline: Fernandez Moves On and Raducanu Returns to Tennis Reality at Indian Wells
text: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Nearly a month after Emma Raducanu and Leylah Fernandez faced off in perhaps the most unexpected Grand Slam singles final, they returned to action as headliners.

headline: Bill Clinton, Race and the Politics of the 1990s
text: My colleague Ezra Klein wrote his latest column on the work of David Shor, a Democratic polling analyst whose primary message is a critique of the Democratic Party, namely that its college-educated professional class is too removed from the working-class, non-college-educated voters they need to win. Here’s Ezra with a little more detail:

headline: Moderna, Racing for Profits, Keeps Covid Vaccine Out of Reach of Poor
text: Moderna, whose coronavirus vaccine appears to be the world’s best defense against Covid-19, has been supplying its shots almost exclusively to wealthy nations, keeping poorer countries waiting and earning billions in profit.

headline: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, Former Iranian President, Dies at 88
text: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, who as the first president of the Islamic Republic of Iran tried and failed to resist the currents of religious radicalism, died on Saturday at the Pitié-Salpêtrière hospital in Paris. He was 88.

headline: The Supreme Court v. Reality
text: WASHINGTON — Ordinarily staid and silent Supreme Court justices have become whirling dervishes of late, spinning madly to rebut the idea that Americans are beginning to regard the court as a dangerous cabal of partisan hacks.

headline: The Team Heard Round the World
text: I once watched a Cincinnati Bengals wild-card matchup on my phone in Auckland, New Zealand. It was a terrible idea. Not because of my phone or the huge time difference, but because my team managed to fall apart in an apocalyptically terrible fashion.

headline: Gender-Neutral Pronouns: The Singular ‘They’ and Alternatives
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Portrait Inspired by the Bright Colors of Los Angeles
text: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-seen work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a piece by the painter Amoako Boafo that appears in his solo exhibition “Singular Duality: Me Can Make We,” on view at Roberts Projects in Los Angeles through November 6.

headline: Moshe Tendler, Authority on Jewish Medical Ethics, Dies at 95
text: One of the stories that recalls Rabbi Moshe Tendler’s charming candor starts out like a timeworn Jewish joke.

headline: In Candid Photos, Shannen Doherty Shows the Ravages of Breast Cancer
text: One picture shows the actress Shannen Doherty completely bald, a bloody cotton ball in her nose as she stares straight at the camera, looking almost confrontational.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
text: ACROSTIC — I absolutely inched through this puzzle, and I find a majority of the entry difficult, even in hindsight. My theory is that this was intentional on the part of our constructors, to give us a challenging puzzle about a challenging topic.

headline: 52 Years in 11 Days: A Son, Facing Death, Finds His Father
text: FALLS CHURCH, Va. — Three weeks before he died, Sam Anthony, 52, mailed his last wishes to a man he had never met.

headline: ‘I Never Believed That Would Happen’: After 20 Years of War, an Abrupt End
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — By the time Ghulam Maroof Rashid’s 50th birthday passed, he had spent more than one-third of his life fighting for the Taliban on one battlefield or another in Afghanistan. He believed they would eventually win the war but had no idea that this year would finally be its end.

headline: When Child Care Costs Twice as Much as the Mortgage
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — To understand the problems Democrats hope to solve with their supersized plan to make child care better and more affordable, consider this small Southern city where many parents spend more for care than they do for mortgages, yet teachers get paid like fast food workers and centers cannot hire enough staff.

headline: Facing Criminal Inquiry, Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz Resigns
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Sebastian Kurz of Austria announced on Saturday that he would resign, days after prosecutors began a criminal investigation into allegations he used public money to pay off pollsters and journalists for favorable coverage.

headline: Stop the Debt Ceiling Nonsense
text: In finally reaching an agreement this week to raise the federal debt ceiling, ensuring that the United States can pay its bills for the next few months, the members of the U.S. Senate have performed a public service roughly akin to that of a would-be arsonist who pockets the matchbook and walks away from the straw.

headline: The College Admissions Scandal: Where Some of the Defendants Are Now
text: The first two people to stand trial in the college admissions bribery scandal were found guilty on Friday. But the two defendants, Gamal Abdelaziz, a former casino executive, and John Wilson, a private equity investor, both parents, joined a list of dozens of figures who have received judgments through plea agreements in the case that federal investigators call Operation Varsity Blues.

headline: Vaccine hesitancy, an issue among police officers, is also evident among firefighters.
text: Vaccine hesitancy among police officers in the United States has been one of the themes of pandemic news this year, but in some places, firefighters are joining the resistance.

headline: Passenger’s ‘Erratic Behavior’ Draws Emergency Response at La Guardia
text: Firefighters and police personnel converged on a plane that had traveled from Indianapolis and landed at La Guardia Airport on Saturday afternoon after a “security incident,” according to a Federal Aviation Administration spokesman.

headline: Populist Leader of Czech Republic Narrowly Defeated in Election
text: PRAGUE — In a blow to Europe’s once surging populist politicians, the prime minister of the Czech Republic, a pugnacious businessman who has compared himself to Donald Trump and railed against migrants, suffered a surprising defeat in a parliamentary election that ended on Saturday.

headline: Joe Manchin’s Choices on Family Policy
text: There is an interesting counterfactual scenario for the now-flailing Biden presidency, where the president responded to the initial success of his bipartisan infrastructure push — all those Republicans at the White House, signing up for billions in new spending — by immediately going out and saying, let’s do the same for family policy.

headline: Canadian Admits Fabricating Terrorism Tale Detailed in New York Times Podcast
text: OTTAWA — A Canadian man admitted in court on Friday that he made up tales about serving as an Islamic State fighter and executioner in Syria. In exchange, Canadian authorities dropped criminal charges against him of perpetrating a hoax involving the threat of terrorism.

headline: ‘Clue’: The Movie
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is one of those sliced-bread themes that makes you wonder why nobody thought of it before, the mark of a great invention. We get movie puzzles (which are always fun) and we get a mystery every so often (please, if you missed it, solve “McGuffin Manor” next). But it took Brandon Koppy to make the connection that makes this puzzle’s theme, as far as I know, so I give him applause.

headline: Bolshoi Performer Is Killed in Onstage Accident
text: A performer was killed during an opera at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow on Saturday when there was an accident during a scene change, the theater said.

headline: Brazil’s Covid-19 death toll passes 600,000.
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil surpassed the grim landmark of more than 600,000 Covid-19 deaths this week, making its death toll second only to the United States.

headline: Man Who Faked Suicide to Avoid Covid-19 Fraud Charges Is Sentenced
text: Three weeks after he had been charged with trying to fraudulently obtain Covid-19 relief loans, David A. Staveley escaped by faking his own suicide, prosecutors said.

headline: About 86 percent of home health aides in New York have met a deadline to be vaccinated.
text: The vaccination rate among home health workers in New York as a deadline arrived on Thursday for them to get Covid shots was about 86 percent, exceeding the expectations of some union and industry leaders and suggesting thousands may have made a last-minute decision to be inoculated, according to preliminary state data.

headline: Here’s how to watch and stream the Wilder-Fury fight.
text: The heavyweight title fight between Tyson Fury and Deontay Wilder will be televised on both Fox Sports’ and ESPN’s pay-per-view platforms in the United States, with a price of $79.99. The pay-per-view card begins at 9 p.m. Eastern on Saturday. And yes, it’s a bit unusual to have two big sports networks carry the same event, though that’s one of the quirks sometimes present in boxing.

headline: A Republican candidate for Texas governor cancels events after Covid exposure.
text: Allen West, the former Republican congressman who is challenging Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas for his seat, has suspended in-person events because he developed Covid symptoms after his wife tested positive for coronavirus on Friday.

headline: Gen. Raymond T. Odierno Dies at 67; Oversaw Iraq Surge
text: Raymond T. Odierno, a four-star Army general who was an influential architect of the surge of American forces during the Iraq war that helped quell sectarian killings and increase stability in the country, died on Friday. He was 67.

headline: Edgar Berlanga got a unanimous decision over Marcelo Esteban Coceres.
text: Edgar Berlanga, a 24-year-old power puncher from Brooklyn, settled in, survived a knockdown, and won a 10-round unanimous decision over Marcelo Esteban Coceres, using forward movement and heavy punches to raise a welt on Coceres’ left eye. All three judges scored the fight 96-93 for Berlanga.

headline: Helenius led big, then won because of Kownacki’s desperate low blows.
text: Late in Round 3, Robert Helenius landed a right hand and left jab that buckled Adam Kownacki’s knees. The salvo was just the latest in a string of combinations Helenius had used to open a lead on the scorecards and raise lumps on his opponent’s face.

headline: Atlanta Beats the Brewers at Their Own Game
text: MILWAUKEE — The Milwaukee Brewers won 95 games during the regular season largely because of the strength of their starting rotation and its three All-Stars: Corbin Burnes, Brandon Woodruff and Freddy Peralta. Only the Los Angeles Dodgers had a lower earned run average than the Brewers’s starting staff.

headline: Iowa Beats Penn State, Staking Claim Atop Big Ten Playoff Contenders
text: On a day that saw 103 combined points in two early afternoon college football games, Iowa and Penn State deviated from the day’s script.

headline: Frank Sanchez wins in a battle among undefeated fighters.
text: Frank Sanchez defeated Efe Ajagba via unanimous decision in Saturday’s co-main event to retain his heavyweight belt and undefeated record.

headline: 87 Rescued From ‘Near-Whiteout’ Conditions During Utah Ultramarathon
text: Kelcey McClung Stowell said she had been told to prepare for some rain and perhaps a “tiny dusting of snow” in the higher elevations before the start on Saturday of the DC Peaks 50, a 50-mile ultramarathon through the rugged mountains of Utah.

headline: Deontay Wilder’s costume is lighter. Fury’s entrance is zanier.
text: Deontay Wilder continued the trend of entering the ring with an exotic costume. This time, though, instead of wearing a heavy armor set, he wore a red robe and red mask. The robe was accented with black feathers around the hood and a pair of silver wings on the back. Wilder claimed the attire he wore before facing Fury in February 2020 weakened his legs, contributing to the first loss of his career. This fashion choice is definitely lighter, so if he loses, that cannot be an excuse.

headline: Quotation of the Day: New York’s Black Pastors Urge Flock to Embrace Vaccine
text: “The kind of conspiracies we saw in the past were real but they do not exist about these vaccines.”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 10, 2021
text: An article last Sunday about the safety of New York City’s new supertall towers misstated the occupancy status of Trump World Tower. It received a final certificate of occupancy from the New York Department of Buildings in 2005; it is not among a number of properties operating under a temporary certificate of occupancy.

headline: Not Even Alabama Is Immune From College Football’s Upset Machine
text: Earlier this year, Texas A&M Coach Jimbo Fisher made a playful declaration.

headline: The 40-Year Mystery of Smutty Smiff and the Missing Rockabilly Bass
text: The moment he saw the standup bass in the Jersey City pawnshop, Stephen Ulrich knew whose it was. It wasn’t just the jet-black paint job with the pink and blue trim that caught his eye. It was the word “SMUTTY” written across the bottom in big pink letters.

headline: Kim Kardashian West Takes Aim at Herself in ‘S.N.L.’ Monologue
text: When it was first announced that Kim Kardashian West would be hosting “Saturday Night Live” this weekend, the feedback was mixed — based on the reaction from some corners, you’d think they had invited Elon Musk or something.

headline: Abdul Qadeer Khan, Father of Pakistan’s Nuclear Program, Dies at 85
text: Abdul Qadeer Khan, a metallurgist who became known to Western intelligence services as the father of Pakistan’s nuclear bomb and a worldwide dealer in weapons technology, died Sunday at a hospital in Islamabad, Pakistan. He was believed to be 85 years old.

headline: A Powerful Story of Coming to America, Finding Promise and Paradox
text: “Why was America so kind and yet so cruel?” Carlos Bulosan wrote in “America Is in the Heart,” his 1943 semi-autobiographical novel about a young Filipino immigrant bewildered by the paradox of his new home. Here, he found racism, callousness and brutality; but he also found good will, tolerance and generosity. “Was there no way to simplify things in this continent so that suffering would be minimized?” Bulosan wrote. “Was there no common denominator on which we could all meet?”

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
text: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: At the George Washington Bridge Casino, Your Bets Are a Bike Ride Away
text: Towering majestically above the Hudson River, the George Washington Bridge is a remarkable feat of engineering to some. For others, it is a snarled, trafficky headache.

headline: He Finds Women on Dating Apps. Then They Disappear.
text: “If you remember me at all, you remember the shy, slight, discomfited and fatherless soul known to inhabit every little nothing town like ours,” Wayland Maynard, ex-resident of Shireburne, Vt., writes to his former neighbors in 2020, in a confessional manuscript describing events that took place more than 40 years earlier.

headline: Where Parents Have Abducted Their Own Children in a Bid for Custody
text: The men and women wrestled Wang Jianna to the ground. Holding down her legs and shoulders, they pried her 6-month-old baby from her arms and took off running.

headline: A Year After ‘Defund,’ Police Departments Get Their Money Back
text: DALLAS — The demonstrators came at night, chanting and blowing whistles outside the home of Mayor Eric Johnson, protesting in occasionally personal terms his staunch refusal to cut funding to the Dallas Police Department.

headline: The Hot New Back-to-School Accessory? An Air Quality Monitor.
text: When Lizzie Rothwell, an architect in Philadelphia, sent her son to third grade this fall, she stocked his blue L.L. Bean backpack with pencils, wide-ruled paper — and a portable carbon dioxide monitor.

headline: Finally Time for ‘No Time to Die’? The Champagne’s Been on Ice.
text: One day before “No Time to Die” started playing in American theaters on Friday, Bollinger, James Bond’s Champagne of choice, held a pre-screening bash at a swanky theater in New York’s South Street Seaport. V.I.P.s in sequined dresses and tuxedos posed for photos on the red carpet, ate caviar and drank a limited edition wine dedicated to 007 — both during the movie and for hours afterward.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The “Perfect Villain” for Voting Conspiracists’
text: Over the past decade, Eric Coomer has helped make Dominion Voting Systems one of the largest providers of voting machines and software in the United States.

headline: Vaccines, Child Care, Canadian Thanksgiving: Your Weekend Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: Facebook’s Rough Stretch
text: Facebook had a tough week. On Monday, the company’s family of apps, including Instagram, WhatsApp and Messenger, went down for more than five hours, disrupting communication for the billions of people and many advertisers who rely on them. (The company said several errors made during maintenance caused the outage). In an interview on “60 Minutes” on Sunday and in testimony at a Senate hearing on Tuesday, Frances Haugen, a former product manager at the company, talked about what she believes is a need for more oversight of the social media giant. Ms. Haugen said that Facebook had purposefully hidden research showing its products’ negative impact on teenagers and was willing to promote harmful content because it caused users to spend more time on the site. She has also spoken with top policymakers in Brussels, Britain and France. Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, rebutted the claims in a note to employees, saying the company’s research had been taken out of context.

headline: Dodgers Turn Around Their Mood With Blowout Win Over Giants
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Almost always positive and upbeat, Los Angeles Dodgers Manager Dave Roberts was not after Game 1 of this National League division series. While everyone else raved about San Francisco starter Logan Webb’s dominance, Roberts chafed. He wasn’t bothered so much by the results as he was by what he viewed as his hitters’ undisciplined approach.

headline: Can Crypto Go Green?
text: The cryptocurrency industry is growing quickly, as are concerns about its environmental impact. The original and most popular crypto, Bitcoin, is energy-intensive by design, “mined” by millions of high-powered computers around the world.

headline: Richard Schultz, Designer Who Made the Outdoors Modern, Dies at 95
text: Richard Schultz, the ingenious industrial designer whose furniture collections for Knoll, the design laboratory that streamlined American interiors, are among the classics of modern design, died on Sept. 28 in Princeton, N.J. He was 95.

headline: Major Climate Action at Stake in Fight Over Twin Bills Pending in Congress
text: WASHINGTON — President Biden has framed this moment as the country’s best chance to save the planet.

headline: Pfizer will vaccinate entire city in Brazil as part of study.
text: In the southwestern Brazilian city of Toledo, you won’t find much vaccine skepticism. About 98 percent of eligible residents there have received at least one dose of a Covid vaccine, according to municipal officials.

headline: For One Bill Cosby Juror, the Work Did Not End With the Trial
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Electricity Is Restored in Lebanon, as Army Supplies Emergency Fuel
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanon’s sputtering national electricity grid went back online on Sunday after the army provided emergency fuel supplies to the government, temporarily easing a daylong outage that served as the latest ramification of the country’s economic collapse.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Good morning. They’re prepping for Thanksgiving in Canada today, brining birds and peeling spuds for the feast on Monday, getting the butter tarts ready, dripping maple syrup into the cranberry sauce, setting tables, engaging in holiday cheer. It’s amazing to think we’ll be following them in just a little more than a month.

headline: Does Instagram Harm Girls? No One Actually Knows.
text: Amid the pillorying of Facebook that has dominated the latest news cycle there is an inconvenient fact that critics have overlooked: No research — by Facebook or anyone else — has demonstrated that exposure to Instagram, a Facebook app, harms teenage girls’ psychological well-being.

headline: How to Help Prepare Kids for Suffering
text: Last year, my sister was asked to write an article on how to make holidays fun for children in the middle of the pandemic. On a walk, we brainstormed about ways to celebrate without group gatherings. We wanted a respite for kids after a dark, hard year.

headline: Don’t Fear a Deafer Planet
text: In Deaf culture, we have a rich storytelling tradition, including a stable of myths passed down through generations of deaf people. One of these stories is about a planet called Eyeth, a utopic world where deaf people communicate freely and live without stigma. Rather than the audio-centric societies that dominate Earth, Eyeth centers the eye. In some tellings everyone on the planet is deaf; in others, the society is designed around visual communication and signed language, and everyone signs regardless of hearing status.

headline: The Rich Have Found Another Way to Pay Less Tax
text: Congress tucked a provision into the 2017 tax bill that led to the creation of 8,764 tax havens across the United States called opportunity zones.

headline: Abortion Rights and Trans Rights Are Two Sides of the Same Coin
text: Caitlyn Jenner’s run for California governor concluded last month, having earned her a whopping 1 percent of the final votes cast.

headline: Sex Positivity, Pornography and Feminism
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Street Basketball Mecca Gets a Face-Lift
text: As a child, Michele Roberts occasionally found herself at Holcombe Rucker Park when her older brothers, who were supposed to be babysitting her at home in the South Bronx, would take her to Harlem instead.

headline: ‘It’s Not Sustainable’: What America’s Port Crisis Looks Like Up Close
text: SAVANNAH, Ga. — Like toy blocks hurled from the heavens, nearly 80,000 shipping containers are stacked in various configurations at the Port of Savannah — 50 percent more than usual.

headline: After Killings, U.K. Asks: Should Misogyny Be a Hate Crime?
text: LONDON — As anger grew in Britain last week over the justice system’s approach to violence against women, the public discourse has turned to a new question: Should misogyny be considered a hate crime?

headline: Black Lives Matter, She Wrote. Then ‘Everything Just Imploded.’
text: CENTREVILLE, Md. — When Andrea Kane sat down to write a letter to parents in her school district days after George Floyd’s death in 2020, images of the Black man pleading for his life under the knee of a white Minnesota police officer were haunting her.

headline: Review: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra Returns, With Gusto
text: NEWARK, New Jersey — Since becoming the music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra in 2016, the dynamic conductor Xian Zhang has worked steadily to reflect diversity and inclusion through the institution’s programming, outreach initiatives and guest artists. This was crucial in a city where a majority of residents were Black and Latino; it also spoke to Zhang’s own experience as one of a small number of Asian female conductors leading major ensembles. These priorities were in evidence on Friday when, 557 days after its last full orchestra concert (because of the pandemic), the New Jersey Symphony opened its new season at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center on a balmy night in Newark.

headline: ‘Go out there and enjoy Halloween,’ Dr. Fauci says.
text: Despite the wide availability of Covid-19 vaccines, not all Halloween parades have been safe from virus-related cancellations this year.

headline: One Killed and at Least 14 Wounded in Shooting in Minnesota Bar, Police Say
text: One person was killed and at least 14 others were wounded during a shooting early on Sunday morning inside a crowded bar in St. Paul, Minn., the authorities said.

headline: Iraqis’ Frustration Over Broken Promises Keeps Voter Turnout Low
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqis voted Sunday in parliamentary elections meant to herald sweeping change to a dysfunctional political system that has dragged the country through almost two decades of deprivation.

headline: After 18 months, the Port of San Francisco will once again welcome cruise ships.
text: In the early days of the pandemic, a cruise ship that would become one of the bellwethers of the outbreak, the Grand Princess, docked in the Bay Area carrying dozens of infected passengers. It was one of the last cruise ships in the world to operate before the coronavirus caused a global shutdown.

headline: Southwest Airlines’ Widespread Cancellations Disrupt Weekend Travel
text: Southwest Airlines canceled more than 1,000 flights on Sunday and just over 800 on Saturday, wreaking havoc on weekend travel plans for thousands of passengers.

headline: ‘What Have We Done With Democracy?’ A Decade On, Arab Spring Gains Wither
text: TUNIS, Tunisia — For roughly three months after Tunisians toppled their dictator in January 2011 in an eruption of protest that electrified the Arab world, Ali Bousselmi felt nothing but “pure happiness.”

headline: After Whistle-Blower Goes Public, Facebook Tries Calming Employees
text: SAN FRANCISCO — At a question-and-answer session with employees last week, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, was asked about Frances Haugen, a former product manager turned whistle-blower who had testified to Congress about the company’s harms.

headline: No Charges for Passenger Who Prompted La Guardia Emergency Landing
text: A passenger whose erratic behavior prompted pilots to make an emergency landing at La Guardia Airport on Saturday afternoon was not charged after the authorities determined that he “did not make a verbal threat” and was not carrying a suspicious item, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

headline: U.S. Navy Engineer Charged in Attempt to Sell Nuclear Submarine Secrets
text: WASHINGTON — A nuclear engineer for the U.S. Navy and his wife have been charged with trying to share some of the United States’ most closely held secrets on submarine technology with another country, according to court documents unsealed on Sunday.

headline: What the Malaria Vaccine Means for Africa
text: Like many who work in public health, especially in sub-Saharan Africa, I’ve been waiting my whole career for a malaria vaccine. And even longer than that: I suffered from severe malaria when I was 10.

headline: Democrats, You’re in Danger
text: The Democrats are staring down real danger.

headline: Are the Jets and Giants Watchable Yet?
text: Time is a flat circle, but we want to help you break it. To that end, we’ve enlisted two experts — one familiar with the ins and outs of New York’s football teams, the other a nationally focused football analyst — to answer an essential question as a service to readers: Is this team good yet?

headline: A Coach’s Vaccine Refusal Generates Discord at Washington State
text: PULLMAN, Wash. — With the leaves beginning to turn and the chilly air snapping skin to attention, Washington State’s football players awoke Saturday to a crisp fall morning. Walking into Martin Stadium through a gantlet of fans, parents, cheerleaders and a marching band only amplified their anticipation.

headline: James Bond Returns and Theaters See Reason for Hope
text: LOS ANGELES — Movie theaters are finally bouncing back from the pandemic, with solid turnout over the weekend for the latest James Bond spectacle, “No Time to Die,” giving Hollywood its third box office success in the span of a month. For coronavirus-battered multiplex chains, it’s reason for a celebratory martini.

headline: Review: In ‘Herstory of the Universe,’ Ancient Myths Are Brought to Life
text: If not for the crowd gathered around, you could have missed her: reclining in the branches of a tree, as if dozing in her natural habitat, a woman adorned in feathers and tulle. At the brisk ring of a bell, she started to stir, arching her sinewy back, the beginning of a delicate descent down to Earth from her comfortable perch.

headline: Wilder-Fury Yields Not Another Rematch, but a Path to a Unified Title
text: Late in the 10th round of their heavyweight title fight on Saturday, Tyson Fury floored Deontay Wilder with a clubbing right hand to the jaw, and the end of their brawl seemed imminent. But Wilder climbed off the canvas and spent the late stages of the round landing heavy punches as Fury covered up.

text: Vaccines were supposed to be the city-state’s ticket back to normalcy. But even with an 83 percent vaccination rate, Singapore is not opening up.

headline: Put Off Until Later
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Monday, solvers! Today we have an impressively constructed grid from Ben Pall. Mr. Pall is a software developer who made his debut in the New York Times Crossword nearly 12 years ago at the age of 14, making him (at the time) the youngest constructor of the Will Shortz era, although he has since been dethroned by the debut of the then-13-year-old Daniel Larsen.

headline: There Is Shadow Inflation Taking Place All Around Us
text: Inflation has surged in 2021, with various official measurements of consumer prices rising faster than they have in years. But in a crucial respect, the data may be understating things.

headline: They Were Promised a New Home. Then They Tried to Escape It.
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Its name translates into “floating island,” and for up to 100,000 desperate war refugees, the low-slung landmass is supposed to be home.

headline: Austrian Political Scandal Leaves Europe’s Conservatives in Need of New Path
text: BERLIN — When Sebastian Kurz first became chancellor of Austria the whole of Europe sat up. Only 31, he had turned around the fortunes of his ailing conservative party and almost overnight become a role model for struggling center-right leaders elsewhere on the Continent.

headline: Something Shook New Hampshire. What Caused the Boom Is a Mystery.
text: A mysterious boom jolted New Hampshire and at least one adjoining state on Sunday morning, rattling homes, spooking pets and prompting several hundred amateur sleuths to go online to try to find out what possibly could have caused all the commotion.

headline: Giants Lose Daniel Jones and Saquon Barkley Against Cowboys

text: Continuing the good vibes from one performance to the next can be tough, it turns out, when you switch out all of your top performers.

headline: A Tough (Correct) Call and a Walk-Off Homer Have the Rays on the Brink
text: BOSTON — Christian Vazquez’s night began on the bench. It ended with a triumphant jog around the bases.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Amid a national outcry in Britain over gender-based crimes, including the murder of Sarah Everard by a London police officer, the public discourse has turned to a new question: Should misogyny be considered a hate crime?

headline: Inside the Massive and Costly Fight Against the Dixie Fire
text: To battle the nearly one-million-acre Dixie fire, California launched a military-style operation. Some experts wonder whether that approach is sustainable.

text: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 11-17. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: The City of London Is Hiding the World’s Stolen Money
text: In 1969, two years after the Cayman Islands, a British territory, passed its first law to allow secretive offshore trusts, an official government report struck an ominous note. A tide of glossy propositions from private developers, it warned, was washing through the islands. Cayman was fast becoming a state captured by shady finance.

headline: Chicago’s Crowd, and Its Offense, Comes Alive Against the Astros
text: CHICAGO — The first two of games of this American League division series between the Houston Astros and the Chicago White Sox were decidedly one-sided. The Astros outscored their opponent by a combined 15-5 and came into Sunday needing only one more victory to advance to their fifth straight A.L. Championship Series. The White Sox, winners of a weaker division, looked overmatched.

headline: Inside Rikers: Dysfunction, Lawlessness and Detainees in Control
text: When a detainee decided to hijack a bus inside the Rikers Island jail complex, little was in place to stop him.

text: President Biden has proclaimed Monday, Oct. 11, as Indigenous Peoples’ Day, becoming the first U.S. president to formally recognize the day.

text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Artistic Aromas of Anicka Yi
text: Six years ago, the artist Anicka Yi created an exhibition on a theme that now feels eerily prescient: human fears of viral contagion. After an Ebola case was confirmed in New York, unsettling city life and causing months of anxiety, Yi set up tents at The Kitchen arts venue in Manhattan to display petri dishes containing bacteria she had gathered from 100 women.

headline: The Chaos on Rikers Island
text: It’s Monday. We’ll look at the chaos inside the jail complex on Rikers Island. Scroll down and we’ll also look at a privately run park in Little Italy that the city wants to evict.

headline: Word of the Day: echelon
John le Carré’s Last Completed Spy Novel Crowns a Career Attuned to Moral Ambivalence
text: SILVERVIEW By John le Carré

headline: Samantha Bee Talks Marjorie Taylor Greene and the Trumps
text: The 45th president may have been ripe material for (dark) comedy, but Samantha Bee sure does not miss him. After covering Donald Trump for six seasons on her late night show “Full Frontal With Samantha Bee,” she says, “Comedy is better without him. Just the world in general, — the globe — is better without him.” She now has airtime to double down her coverage of other challenges like climate change and the affront to voting and abortion rights.

headline: We Are Republicans. There’s Only One Way to Save Our Party From Pro-Trump Extremists.
text: After Donald Trump’s defeat, there was a measure of hope among Republicans who opposed him that control of the party would be up for grabs, and that conservative pragmatists could take it back. But it’s become obvious that political extremists maintain a viselike grip on the national and state parties and the process for fielding and championing House and Senate candidates in next year’s elections.

headline: October Isn’t Just a Month Anymore. It’s a Whole Szn.
text: October marks the start of myriad unofficial seasons: spooky season, pumpkin spice season, cuffing season, cozy season, hoodie season and, of course, decorative gourd season. (Or “szn,” for those inclined to abbreviate.)

headline: How to Prevent the Worst Case Extinction Scenario
text: NASHVILLE — If you’re a certain age, you may remember the snail darter, a small fish in the Little Tennessee River that caused an environmental firestorm when it was listed as endangered in 1975. At the time, the Tennessee Valley Authority was already in the midst of building a dam on the Little Tennessee. Snail darters require free-flowing water to reproduce, and the only known habitat for the entire species was about to be dammed.

headline: ‘This Drop Came So Quickly’: Shrinking Schools Add to Hong Kong Exodus
text: HONG KONG — Long before the school year began, Chim Hon Ming, a primary school principal in Hong Kong, knew this year’s student body would be smaller. The city’s birthrate had already been falling, and families were increasingly frustrated by Hong Kong’s strict pandemic restrictions and the political turmoil.

headline: Moving to a Crown Heights Apartment Allowed Her to Nurture a Green Thumb
text: Jaclyn Baird really wanted her desk to be a work space, but the plants have taken over.

headline: As E-Scooters and E-Bikes Proliferate, Safety Challenges Grow
text: The coronavirus pandemic has upended many of the familiar routines that make up everyday urban life, bringing tectonic shifts in office culture, classroom learning and online shopping.

headline: There’s More Than One Way to Play Dead
text: Gail Collins: Bret, October is my favorite month. And now that the Senate has decided not to default on the national debt, really, what could be better?

headline: Inside the Courtroom With Theranos’s Elizabeth Holmes
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Three days a week, Adriana Kratzmann, an administrator, opens the door at 8:30 a.m. to Courtroom 4 of the Robert F. Peckham Federal Building and U.S. Courthouse.

headline: The End of Gender
text: One of the biggest trends of the spring 2022 fashion shows that just ended was not any particular silhouette or color, but rather the fact that many designers put both women and men on their runways in what once would have been termed “women’s wear” — not so much as provocation but simply as a matter of fact. Here, our two critics debate why, and what that may signify in terms of gender identity, sexuality and society.

headline: Agony and Ecstasy on the Scottish Archipelago of St. Kilda
text: For the first hour or so, the water was relatively calm. After departing from the small fishing village of Stein on the Isle of Skye, we sped through a strait known as the Little Minch toward the main band of the Outer Hebrides, the thick curl of rocky skerries that hovers like an apostrophe over the northwestern coast of mainland Scotland.

headline: Sydney roars back to life as pubs and stores open after three months.
text: SYDNEY, Australia — With excitement and caution, Sydney stepped out of lockdown Monday after more than 100 days of Delta-diminished existence.

headline: Fighting the Dixie Fire
text: Wildfires have always been a normal part of life in the American West. During a typical year in the late 20th century, fires burned about 500,000 acres a year in California — an area equal to roughly half the size of Rhode Island.

headline: The Ephemeral Beauty of Night-Blooming Flowers
text: BY DAY, HYLOCEREUS undatus resists friendship. A climbing cactus native to Mexico and Central America but now thriving in regions tropical and temperate around the world, it can grow more than 30 feet tall, colonizing trees and rock walls with extended, fleshy stems, massed like the arms of an octopus. All year it sprawls, a spiked barricade — and then, one night, the flowers come. Starting around dusk (depending on where in the world you are, how warm the day, the ponderousness of clouds), the pale, waxy buds, which resemble elongated artichokes, start to open, the pink-tipped sepals peeling back millimeter by millimeter until, by midnight, the secret is told: the blossom announcing itself, so white it seems to glow, with skinny yellow streamers at its throat. Its life is a matter of hours; in the light of day, it retreats and shrivels, a ball gown turned to rags.

headline: Here’s how to watch the Boston Marathon.
text: After being delayed by 18 months because of the pandemic, the Boston Marathon is back this year, marking its 125th anniversary.

headline: Severe Weather Sweeps Across Southern Plains, Producing at Least Two Tornadoes
text: A band of severe weather moving across Oklahoma late Sunday and into Monday spawned at least two tornadoes and prompted a wave of warnings, a weather official said. There were no immediate reports of injuries or deaths.

headline: A Modernist Gem in Paris, Meticulously Restored
text: ÉRIC TOUCHALEAUME WAS a teenager in the late 1960s when his cultured, peripatetic parents moved the family from Bordeaux to the Auteuil section of Paris’s posh 16th Arrondissement. Now in his 60s, the prominent dealer of mid-20th-century French design spent those early days exploring his new neighborhood on the edge of the Bois de Boulogne, winding past recherché centuries-old homes with bisque stone facades and quiet courtyards.

headline: Fight or Flight

headline: The Hand-Beaded Chanel Bag That Takes 120 Hours to Embroider
text: The origins of Chanel’s classic flap handbags can be traced back to February 1955, when the house’s founder, Gabrielle “Coco” Chanel, created her first pocketbook with a shoulder strap. Like most of her ideas, that purse, dubbed the 2.55 (to commemorate the month and year it was introduced), had feminist underpinnings: The strap allowed women to keep their hands free instead of clutching a handle. In 1983, Karl Lagerfeld, the label’s longtime creative director, subtly updated the 2.55, replacing the simple twist Mademoiselle clasp with interlocking C’s, and would go on to make other modifications. The reinterpreted bag was named the 11.12, evoking the internal style code of Lagerfeld’s medium-size version, the A01112. But while the shape of the purse has remained consistent through the decades, Chanel continues to iterate its embellishments, capitalizing on the house’s small specialist craft ateliers, called Métiers d’art.

headline: In Rolling Over Chiefs, Bills Encounter Little Resistance

Ignoring the organization’s portfolio of postseason fiascos, its half-century of stepping on land mines, he assessed the Chiefs’ infrastructure — their inventive coaching staff, resourceful front office and nucleus of young talent — and forecast a dynasty.

And yet, “My Dinner With André” is just as fresh 40 years later.

headline: Loans Will Be the Key to Banks’ Future Fortunes
text: As investors brace for underwhelming earnings reports across much of the business world, the country’s biggest banks are expected to report solid profits this week, thanks to the central role they play in the reopening economy.

headline: Gin With a Hint of Mangosteen
text: Gin knows no boundaries. From its beginnings centuries ago, it has become a worldwide spirit distinguished by the presence of juniper. A new entry in the category — now riding a wave of popularity — is from Hanoi, Vietnam, with two gins bearing the Song Cai label. Each displays a different flavor profile; both are distilled with native botanicals foraged by families in rural communities that in turn receive support from the company. Only the necessary juniper is imported. Viet Nam Dry Gin, clean and lively on the palate, with a hint of lime leaf dancing with juniper, will flatter your martini. Viet Nam Floral Gin, fragrant and richly endowed with notes of mangosteen, cardamom and citrus, deserves to be sipped on the rocks. Each is 90 proof. The gins have been made since 2018, but are only now available in the U.S.

headline: The Secrets of Pizza Perfection
text: Nobody can slice and dice a food topic, with vibrant photos along the way, like Nathan Myhrvold and his team at Modernist Cuisine. They have now tackled pizza. Are you ready for more than 1,000 recipes? They’re in the three massive volumes, plus a kitchen primer, covering history, science, equipment, recipes, trivia, technical details, ingredients, innovations and culture across the globe. They explain how to flavor fior di latte mozzarella, suggest what to do with leftover pizza and how to troubleshoot. In a first for the books, there is a chapter on where to find what the authors consider great pizza in more than 25 cities, in the United States and abroad, the result of visiting more than 250 pizzerias.

headline: A New Fuel for the Tailgate
text: Yes, it’s no longer summer grilling season. But how about tailgating or lighting the grill in the glow of early autumn with a new fuel? Agricycle, a company that repurposes agricultural waste, has introduced Tropicoal Ignition, effective charcoal briquettes for grilling that are made by smallholder farmers and women- and youth-led cooperatives throughout Africa from discarded coconut shells, palm kernel shells and cassava starch. The briquettes are completely natural, have no chemical ingredients and burn hotter than charcoals made of wood to quickly and cleanly sear those pork chops or slabs of eggplant.

headline: A Bonbon With Benefits
text: These chocolates are the treat of the two Jacques. To benefit the Jacques Pépin Foundation, the chocolatier Jacques Torres has created bonbons draped in dark chocolate with a ganache filling spiked generously with Woodford Reserve bourbon, a favorite of Mr. Torres and a supporter of the foundation. The sale of each box of 12 includes a one-year membership in the Foundation at the commis level, which allows access to recipes and cooking videos with Mr. Pépin and other chefs. The chocolates can be ordered only from Oct. 12 through Nov. 12 and will be delivered in early December.

headline: Pick a Card, Any Card, for Dinner Inspiration
text: Here’s a cunning little gift that gives back. Maggie Tang, Alaina Chou and Amy Yang, students at the University of Pennsylvania, have created a deck of cards with food illustrations from 52 New York restaurants. The selection includes Adda, Carbone, Don Angie, Katz’s Deli, Crown Shy, Olmsted and Via Carota. The project is supported by S. Pellegrino, Acqua Panna and Bentobox, and $3 of each deck will be donated to ROAR (Restaurants Organizing, Advocating & Rebuilding). It’s a project of Gourmand, an organization Ms. Tang and Ms. Chou founded to inspire an emerging generation of food lovers with events, podcasts and other features; it has spread to more than 10 campuses. The cards can be ordered starting Monday and will be delivered starting in November.

headline: Who Really Controls Local Politics?
text: In November 2020, Nithya Raman, a 40-year-old former urban planner, unseated a well-funded fellow Democrat and thoroughly endorsed incumbent named David Ryu to win the Los Angeles City Council seat for Council District 4 (CD-4). It’s an amoeba-shaped area that encompasses the tony hills of Silver Lake, where Raman lives, sweeps down through the ultrawealthy avenues of Hancock Park, pushes out past the 18 high-rise apartment buildings of Park LaBrea, travels through working- and middle-class sections of the Los Feliz flats and Hollywood, runs up the Hollywood Hills and finally spills out into the suburb of Sherman Oaks.

headline: Doing Economics as if Evidence Matters
text: Nobel Memorial Prizes in economics are given for long-term research, not for economists’ role in current debates, so they don’t necessarily have much bearing on the political moment. You might expect the disconnect to be especially strong when the prize is given mainly for the development of new research methods.

headline: After a Long Wait, the Boston Marathon Returns as a Fall Classic

headline: Cause for a Correction
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to today’s constructor, Conor Sefkow, for making his New York Times Crossword debut! This puzzle is built around a term that Mr. Sefkow coined himself and just knew he had to build a puzzle around. I love hearing the origin stories of creative themes like this one (described in more detail below), and I am particularly fond of clever portmanteaus, which, as far as I’m concerned, are the height of wit.

headline: Kristalina Georgieva will remain managing director of the I.M.F., its board says.
text: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund’s executive board on Monday expressed confidence in the leadership of Kristalina Georgieva, its managing director, after allegations that she manipulated data to placate China when she was a senior World Bank official.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Thirty-two countries have joined the U.S. in a pact developed with the E.U. to reduce methane emissions 30 percent by 2030. It is part of an effort to set new targets to slow global warming before a major U.N. climate summit in Glasgow next month.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Large and Costly Battle to Contain a Megafire
text: “Fifteen years ago, a 100,000-acre fire would be the largest fire of your career. Now, we have one-million-acre fires. We’re the size of Rhode Island, working toward Delaware.”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 12, 2021
text: The Saturday Profile about Lamont Marcell Jacobs, the Italian sprinter who won two gold medals in the Tokyo Olympics, misstated Italy’s medal count in athletics events, which include track and field, at the games. The country won five gold medals in athletics events, not 10.

headline: North Korea Displays Large Missile Arsenal Amid Stalled Talks
text: SEOUL — North Korea on Monday showed off its growing arsenal of missiles in one of its largest-ever exhibitions of military gear, as its leader, Kim Jong-un, said he didn’t believe repeated assertions by the United States that it harbored no hostile intent toward his country.

headline: If You’ve Had Covid, Do You Need the Vaccine?
text: When Jonathan Isaac, a prominent basketball player for the Orlando Magic, explained why he chose not to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, he tapped into a dispute that has been simmering for months: Do people who have had Covid-19, as Mr. Isaac said he has, really need the vaccine?

headline: Past Pandemics Remind Us Covid Will Be an Era, Not a Crisis That Fades
text: The skeletons move across a barren landscape toward the few helpless and terrified people still living. The scene, imagined in a mid-16th-century painting, “The Triumph of Death” by Pieter Bruegel the Elder, illuminated the psychic impact of the bubonic plague.

text: For nearly 250 years, the American flag has been made and remade.  A recent Times article showcased several new updates to the flag, as imagined by six artists and graphic designers.

headline: The Red Sox Ride a Wave of Offense Into the A.L.C.S.
text: BOSTON — So this was how it ended for the Tampa Bay Rays, the team that pushes and pokes conventional thinking and usually gets away with it. The Rays set a franchise record with 100 victories this season, eight more than the Boston Red Sox. But when it mattered most, in their American League division series, the Red Sox upended the hoariest axiom of all.

headline: On a Windy Night in L.A., One Run Is Enough for the Giants

headline: More E-Scooters, More E-Bikes and More Safety Concerns

text: SMALL PLEASURESBy Clare Chambers

headline: How to Play Drunk
text: “Acting drunk convincingly is about the hardest thing you can do,” says D.W. Brown, 60, an acting coach based in Santa Monica, Calif., who has worked with both film and stage actors. There are famous film scenes for which actors are said to have drunk alcohol, but getting intoxicated for real is ill advised, especially for stage actors, who perform the same scene day after day. Figure out how to fake it instead, which will require practiced motor-skill impairment and discernible psychological shifts.
